Introduction

Health Records must be managed appropriately to support the day to day corporate activities of the Trust's business including patient care and continuity of care, meeting legal requirements, supporting decision making and assisting medical and other audits.

The purpose of the policy is to ensure all users within the MSE Group are aware of their responsibilities relating to the storage, tracking, retrieval, retention, archiving and destruction of health records.
The MSE Group has legal obligations for health records management that are set out in this policy and the associated guidance. Acts include, but are not restricted to:
Freedom on Information Act 2000;
Access to Health Records Act 1990;
Access to Medical Records Act 1988;
Human Rights Act 1988;
Health & Social Care Act 2012;
Computer Misuse Act 1990;
General Data Protection Regulations 2016;
Data Protection Act 2018

All Trust staff that use or are involved in the management of health records have a responsibility for maintaining good record keeping practice, whether that record is held electronically in an Electronic Patient Record (EPR) system or in hard copy.

It should be noted that certain departments for operational reasons may retain other health records in their area (e.g. maternity, A&E, physiotherapy etc). Whilst this is permissible these records must be retained in accordance with the policy and the Records Management Code of Practice for Health and Social Care 2016.
Pathology departments retain, store and archive their records and samples in line with the Royal College of Pathology guidelines and EU regulations.

Each site within the MSE Group currently operates different processes with regard to the management of patient's healthcare records and this policy is therefore supported by a number of localised Standard Operating Procedures.
The MSE Group Health Records Centres shall provide the following services:
Provide training on health records policies and procedures to Trust staff as appropriate;
Monitor and manage the use of temporary case notes;
Ensure prompt retrieval and distribution of hard copy records to authorised personnel upon receipt of appropriate request;
Provide hard copy case notes for in-patients/day cases and out-patient attendances;
Select case notes for archiving and/or document imaging;
Support the Trust's healthcare governance, risk management and other related systems;
Work in accordance with the Trust's data protection requirements;
Monitor availability of hard copy case notes for all planned attendances including outpatients and elective admissions.
Scope
This policy relates to hard copy clinical records and electronic patient data held across the MSE Group and covers the creation, storage, retention and access to:
Current folders;
Temporary folders;
Multiple volumes (overflow) folders;
Records directly input into electronic patient records systems;
Microfiched / microfilmed records;
Xray images;
All other electronically held clinical information.
This policy relates to any unit where the MSE Group provides clinical services to patients which form part of the Group activity.
This policy excludes the provision of duplicate records or the disclosure of information to any third party. This process is covered by the MSE Group Access to Records Policy.
The site based Health Records Centres do not provide a holding facility for any private patient information.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees) Duties are:

table_items.text: Ratify and monitor policies and action plans to ensure compliance with the Health Records Policy applying to all methods of conveying information and covering the following areas of information governance: Confidentially & data protection assurance; Information security assurance; Secondary use assurance; Corporate information assurance; Records management assurance; Freedom of information.

Monitor the management of patients health records to ensure that the overall objectives and informatics strategy are met and that the organisation complies with professional good practice, current legislation, national policies and guidelines
Review and approve health records policies and procedures to support achievement of health records standards
Approve new or revised EMR documentation

data.text: Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust Duties are:

Chief Executive – has overall responsibility for health records management across the MSE Group, ensuring that the Group complies with all legislation, guidance and standards relating to clinical record keeping, health records management including the infrastructure required to support eh delivery and implementation of this document.

Managing Directors – sites responsibility for supporting the Chief Executive in ensuring all staff with access to personal clinical information comply with all legislation, guidance and standards relating to clinical record keeping and health records management including systems and processes in place to communicate and implement this document.
Chief Operating Officers – site responsibility for ensuring all staff with access to personal clinical information comply with all legislation, guidance and standards.
Directors of Nursing – site responsibility for ensuring that all nursing and midwifery staff comply with all legislation, guidance and standards relating to health records management.

Medical Directors – site responsibility for ensuring all medical and dental staff with access to personal clinical information comply with all legislation, guidance and standards relating to health records management.

Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO) – accountable for ensuring that a culture for protecting and using data is embedded within the MSE Group daily business. To be concerned with the management of all information assets and to provide a focal point for managing information risks and incidents.

Deputy Director of Coding, Data Quality & Health Records – overall responsible for the management and development of the Health Records services and ensuring that processes comply with the relevant governance initiatives.

Health Records Managers – site based responsibility for overall development and maintenance of health records management practices, ensuring that there is an ongoing audit programme for tracking, retention, destruction and standards for health records and for drawing up guidance for good records management practice, and promoting compliance with this policy is such a way as to ensure the easy, appropriate and timely retrieval of patient information.
Health Records Staff – responsible for compliance with this policy and departmental procedures for the lifecycle, storage and retrieval of health records.
All staff who use / handle health – whether clinical or administrative, who create, receive and use health records have a responsibility to ensure that they:

4.2.1 It is the responsibility of the area generating paperwork to ensure that it has been filed correctly in the case note folder. Inpatient documentation is the responsibility of the ward administrator; outpatient documentation is the responsibility of the Medical Secretary.
4.2.2 The Health Records Service will not accept responsibility for filing loose paperwork, it will be returned to the originator unless suitable scanning processes are in place.
Process
NHS / Hospital Numbers

5.1.1 The primary patient identifier is always their NHS Number and this must be recorded on every document created. If the patient does not have an NHS number due to not being registered with any GP within the UK then the hospital number will become their primary indictor until an NHS number has been obtained.

5.1.2 The unique hospital number is a local site number used for internal management of patients and their hard copy case notes. It can also be used as a pseudonym when communicating outside the hospital as long as no other patient identifiable information is provided.

5.1.3 Before creating a new health record staff responsible for registering new patients must ensure that a patient record does not already exist by checking the various EPR systems, and/or the Summary Care Record on the National Spine. Refer to site SOPs for process.
Security and movement of case note folders

5.2.1 The secure movement of hard copy case notes to ensure confidentiality is maintained is a requirement of the Data Security and Protection Toolkit (DSPT) and the GDPR, as well as MSE Group policy.
5.2.2 Special controls should be adopted where necessary to protect sensitive information from unauthorised disclosure or modification:
Use of containers (blue / red boxes) that can be securely tagged closed;
Delivered by hand;
Tamper evident packaging which can include signature across the seal of an envelope and putting sticky tape over it.
5.2.3 The internal mail system must not be used for transporting hard copy case note folders under any circumstance.
5.2.4 Original hard copy case note folders will only be permitted off site for:
Clinics held at a satellite clinic;
Trust led clinics held in the community;
The record is being archived and being collected by the contractor;
Provided to Court following a Court Order (this is managed by the Access to Records Bureau only as a copy of the original records needs to be taken prior to delivery to Court);

Coroners hearing (notes which are to be held by a Coroner and not in the presence of a Trust official must be tracked on the EPR system giving the name of the person who is responsible for the safe keeping of the patient record along with the current contact number).
5.2.5 Health records must not leave site:
For audit or research purposes;
If the patient is being treated at another care provider, NHS or private – in these instances photocopies of the key documents will be provided;
To be taken to staff homes.
5.2.6 All hard copy case note folders required for clinics off site should be collected and delivered by the Trust's Transport.
5.2.7 In all areas the appropriate case note tracking policy must be followed to ensure an audit trail of documentation.

5.2.8 Only the Trust approved courier/taxi companies may be used and a Confidentiality Agreement must be in place prior to the commencement of the service, and must only be used where the risk to patient care would outweigh the risk of a breach of confidentiality or loss.

5.2.9 The MSE Group has a contract with secure storage companies for its offsite storage. The companies are required to use their own employed staff for the purpose of collecting and delivering hard copy case note folders back to the Trust. They are not permitted to sub-contract to a third party and to do so would invalidate their contract.
Operating Hours
5.3.1 The MSE Group site operating hours are:

data.text: 5.3.2 Outside of these hours accessing hard copy case notes is the responsibility of the site clinical operational managers contactable via switchboard or the MSE Systems Managers
Case Note Tracking
5.4.1 All staff are required to electronically track the hard copy case note folders on the appropriate EPR system in line with the appropriate site Case Note Tracking SOP.
5.4.2 Case note folders must be tracked in (received) to a department when they arrive and tracked out (dispatched) when they are sent elsewhere.
Retention and Destruction of Health Records
5.4.1 Health records, whether hard copy or electronic, will be retained in accordance with the NHS Records Management Code of Practice appendices.
5.4.2 Hard copy case note folders are retained on the sites as follows:

table_items.text: 2 years then moved to offsite storage for remainder of retention period
Minimum of 8 whole years from the date of creation
2 years then moved to offsite storage for remainder of retention period

data.text: 5.4.3 Hard copy case note folders held in offsite storage will be reviewed at the end of their appropriate retention period and either retained for a further period or destroyed.
5.4.4 Electronic systems must be regularly reviewed to ensure that electronically stored patient data is deleted at the end of the appropriate retention period.
Training Requirements
Staff who require access to hard copy case note folders should attend health records management training during their induction period.
Ward administrators should receive appropriate instruction in the creation and merging of volumes on the appropriate ERP systems.
All Health Records Centre staff will receive full training during their induction period.
Further training requirements, as identified, can be supported by the Health Records Centre staff.
Monitoring and Audit
This policy will be reviewed regularly and updated in line with national guidelines, legislation or changes to organisational procedures. At a minimum this policy will be reviewed every two years.
This policy should be read in conjunction with other relevant MSE Group and site specific policies and SOPs.
Approval and Implementation
This policy will be reviewed by those named on the list of those consulted with (see page 2) for accuracy, before being presented to the list of approval groups on the front page of this document.
This policy will be ratified by the MSE Group document ratification group before being published on each site's intranet and cascaded via staff communications.
